data.scenario: I recently inherited my childhood home in Sussex following the death of my father. For sentimental reasons, and because it is bigger than my current home, I would like to move into it with my family. This would mean either selling or renting out my current home. I know that you don't have to pay capital gains tax when you sell your own home, but I'm not clear whether my current home would be classed as my main home if I move into the other property.
data.question: Will I pay capital gains tax if I sell my current home in order to move into an inherited property?
evidences: You don’t pay Capital Gains Tax when you sell your home. You do pay it if you make a profit when you sell a property that isn’t your main home.
If inheriting a property means you own 2 homes, you’ll have to nominate one of them as your main home. You must tell HMRC which property is your main home within 2 years of inheriting the property.

evidences: As a tenant, you have the right to:
• challenge excessively high charges
• be protected from unfair eviction and unfair rent
For any tenancy:

evidences: When you buy business assets you can usually deduct the full value from your profits before tax using annual investment allowance (AIA).

data.scenario: I have a small business importing wine from France to sell in the London area.
data.question: Will I have to pay duty and VAT on goods that cost around £150?
evidences: Anything posted or couriered to you from another country goes through customs to check it is not banned or restricted and you pay the right tax and ‘duty’ on it.
This includes anything new or used that you:
• buy online
• buy abroad and send back to the UK
Before receiving your goods, you may have to pay VAT, Customs Duty or Excise Duty if they were sent to:
• Great Britain (England, Wales and Scotland) from outside the UK
You will not have to pay anything to the delivery company to receive goods worth less than £135 unless they’re gifts over £39 or excise goods (for example, alcohol and tobacco).
VAT is charged on all goods (except for gifts worth £39 or less) sent from:
• outside the UK to Great Britain
You’ll be charged Customs Duty on all goods sent from outside the UK (or the UK and the EU if you’re in Northern Ireland) if they’re either:
• excise goods
• worth more than £135
You pay Customs Duty on excise goods of any value.
If you’re sent alcohol or tobacco from outside the UK, you’ll be charged Excise Duty at current rates.

• the rent increase must be fair and realistic, which means in line with average local rents

data.scenario: I rent a room in a house in multiple occupation in Sheffield, England, and have a periodic assured shorthold tenancy agreement with the landlord. Recently, however, he has announced a very large rent increase as part of a "section 13" procedure, to which I and several other tenants in the building strongly object.
data.question: Can we appeal to a housing tribunal over this rent dispute considering we have a shorthold tenancy agreement?
evidences: You can only apply to the tribunal if:
• you have an assured or assured shorthold tenancy

data.scenario: My family and I are private tenants and have been for over five years in the same place. My landlord has just increased our rent out of the blue and we cannot afford the new rate. The fixed-term tenancy agreement has two years remaining.
data.question: Is it acceptable for the landlord to have done this arbitrarily?
evidences: For a fixed-term tenancy (running for a set period) your landlord can only increase the rent if you agree. If you do not agree, the rent can only be increased when the fixed term ends.

data.scenario: I will be attending my CBT course tomorrow in hopes of finally being able to drive the moped my parent bought me for Christmas. I passed the theory test and full moped test last year. I am aware that the course will take me the whole day and my dad suggested he drops me off together with my moped and I drive back once I have my certificate. We have already equipped the vehicle with L plates. The moped I will drive is 50cc.
data.question: Am I going to be allowed to drive back home on my moped after receiving my certificate of completion?
evidences: You can then ride a moped or motorcycle up to 125cc and with a power output of up to 11kW on the road with L plates (L or D plates in Wales).

data.scenario: I am appealing against a decision to deport me on the grounds that I do not have a skilled job here in the UK. I have been here for over ten years from my native Australia and am desperately looking for work but can't find any. The adviser I hired is not helping me at all. This deportation decision was made 18 months ago.
data.question: I want to make a complaint against my immigration advisor, can I?
evidences: You usually cannot make a complaint about something that happened more than 12 months ago - OISC will decide whether or not to investigate depending on the situation.

data.scenario: I am a junior office worker in a large law firm and have been here for eighteen months. I feel that I am being bullied by my immediate supervisor, who encourages other workers to laugh at me too. This is causing me a great deal of distress. I tried to resolve the problem by talking to my manager but I am not happy with his response
data.question: I want to make a formal grievance complaint about my supervisor. Can I?
evidences: If you’re a worker and you’ve tried solving a problem or concern informally by talking to your manager but you’re not satisfied, you can make a formal grievance complaint in writing.
